Receiver Operating Characteristic for Power Lindley Distribution

Source: R/PLindleyROC.R
PLindleyROC.Rd

Receiver operating characteristic (ROC) analysis is carried out from the Power Lindley distribution. Specificity, sensitivity, area under the curve, and ROC curve are evaluated.

Usage

dPLD(x, alpha, beta)

pPLD(x, alpha, beta)

qPLD(p, alpha, beta)

rPLD(n, alpha, beta)

plAUC(alpha1, beta1, alpha2, beta2)

plJ(alpha1, beta1, alpha2, beta2, init = 0)

plER(alpha1, beta1, alpha2, beta2, init = 0)

plCZ(alpha1, beta1, alpha2, beta2, init = 0)

plIU(alpha1, beta1, alpha2, beta2, init = 0)

plNI(alpha1, beta1, alpha2, beta2, init = 0)

plROC(x, y, alpha1, beta1, alpha2, beta2, empirical = TRUE)

prfROC(ctp = 0, alpha1, beta1, alpha2, beta2)

Arguments

x, y

vector of quantiles.

alpha

shape parameter.

beta

scale parameter.

p

vector of probabilities.

n

number of observations. If length(n) > 1, the length is taken to be the number required.

alpha1

shape parameter of first sample.

beta1

scale parameter of first sample.

alpha2

shape parameter of second sample.

beta2

scale parameter of second sample.

init

initial value for the optimization calculation.

empirical

empirical must be TRUE or FALSE.

ctp

cut-off point value.

Value

dPLD gives the probability density function of Power Lindley Distribution.

pPLD gives the cumulative density function of Power Lindley Distribution.

qPLD gives the quantile function of Power Lindley Distribution.

rPLD gives random numbers from Power Lindley Distribution.

plAUC gives area under curve of Power Lindley Distribution. Area under the ROC curve is obtained.

plJ gives Youden's index for Power Lindley Distribution. Youden's J statistics is a way of summarising the performance of a diagnostic test.

plER gives the Closest to (0,1) Criteria (ER) for Power Lindley Distribution. The Closest to (0,1) Criteria (ER) is a way of summarising the performance of a diagnostic test.

plCZ gives the Concordance Probability Method for Power Lindley Distribution. The Concordance Probability Method is a way of summarising the performance of a diagnostic test.

plIU gives the Index of Union for Power Lindley Distribution. The Index of Union is a way of summarising the performance of a diagnostic test.

plNI gives the New Index for Power Lindley Distribution.

plROC gives the ROC graph for Power Lindley Distribution. The ROC graph is given by 1-specificity versus sensitivity.

prfROC gives sensitivity,specificity and 1-specificity for Power Lindley Distribution.

Details

The probability density function (PDF) and cumulative distribution function (CDF) are as follows: $$f\left( x\right) =\frac{\alpha \beta ^{2}}{\beta +1}\left( 1+x^{\alpha} \right) x^{\alpha -1}\exp \left( -\beta x^{\alpha }\right)$$ $$=zg_{1}\left( t\right) +\left( 1-z\right) g_{2}\left( t\right)$$

$$F\left( x\right) =P\left( X\leq x\right) =1-\left( 1+zx^{\alpha } \right) \exp \left( -\beta x^{\alpha }\right)$$ and quantile function is given by, $$Q\left( u\right) =F^{-1}\left( u\right) =\left\{ -\frac{W\left( \left( 1+\beta \right) \left( -1+u\right) \exp \left( -\left( 1+\beta \right) \right) \right) +1+\beta } {\beta }\right\} ^{\frac{1}{\alpha }}$$ ,where $$z =\frac{\beta }{\beta +1}$$ $$g_{1}\left( x\right) =\alpha \beta x^{\alpha -1}\exp \left( -\beta x^{\alpha }\right)$$ $$g_{2}\left( x\right) =\alpha \beta ^{2}x^{2\alpha -1}\exp \left(-\beta x^{\alpha }\right)$$ \(\alpha>0\) is a shape parameter, \(\beta>0\) is a scale parameter, \(0<u<1\) and \(W\) is Lambert W function.

Let \(c\) be the cut-off point, \(X_{1}\sim PL\left( \alpha_{1}, \beta_{1}\right) \) and \(X_{2}\sim PL\left( \alpha_{2},\beta_{2}\right) \) with \(\alpha_{2}>\alpha_{1}\). \(F_{1}\) and \(F_{2}\) are the cumulative distribution functions related to \(X_{1}\) and \(X_{2}\), respectively. In that case, the 1-specificity (False Positive Rate,FPR) and sensitivity (True Positive Rate,TPR) are given by, $$FPR =P\left( X_{1}>c\right) =1-P\left( X_{1}\leq c\right) =1-F_{1} \left(c\right)$$ $$TPR =1-F_{2}\left( Q_{1}\left( 1-FPR\right) \right)$$ and Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) curve can be expressed as follows: $$ROC =\left\{\left(r,( 1-F_{2}\left( Q_{1}\left( 1-r; \boldsymbol{\theta }\right) \right), r\in \left( 0,1\right) \right)\right\}$$, where \(\boldsymbol{\theta }=\left( \alpha _{1},\alpha _{2}, \beta _{1},\beta_{2}\right)\).

Performance assesments for the ROC analysis are as follows: $$AUC =\int\limits_{0}^{1}ROCdr$$ $$J\left( c\right) =\underset{c}{\arg \max } \left\{ \left( 1-F_{2}\left( c\right) \right) +F_{1}\left( c\right) -1\right\}$$ $$ER\left( c\right) = \underset{c}{\arg \min } \left\{ \sqrt{\left( 1-F_{1}\left( c\right) \right) ^{2}+\left( F_{2}\left( c\right) \right) ^{2}} \right\}$$ $$CZ\left( c\right) = \underset{c}{\arg \max } \left\{ \left( 1-F_{2}\left( c\right) \right) \times F_{1}\left( c\right) \right\}$$ $$IU\left( c\right) =\left\{ \left\vert \left( 1-F_{2}\left( c\right) -AUC\right) \right\vert +\left\vert F_{1}\left( c\right) -AUC\right\vert \right\}$$ $$NI\left( c\right) =\underset{c}{\arg \max }\left\{ \left( \left( 1-F_{1}\left( c\right) \right) \times F_{2}\left( c\right) \times F_{1}\left( c\right) \times \left( 1-F_{2}\left( c\right) \right) \right) \right. \nonumber \\ \left. +\left( F_{1}\left( c\right) \times F_{2}\left( c\right) \times \left( 1-F_{1}\left( c\right) \right) \times \left( 1-F_{2}\left( c\right) \right) \right) \right\}$$ ,where AUC is area under the ROC curve, J is Youden's J index, ER is the closest to \(\left( 0,1\right)\) criteria, CZ is the concordance probability method, IU is index of Union and NI is new index.

References

Akgenç, E., and Kuş, C., 2023, ROC Curve Analysis for the Measurements Distributed Power-Lindley Distribution, 2nd International E-Conference On Mathematical And Statistical Sciences: A Selçuk Meeting (ICOMSS-2023), Konya, 25.

Attwood, K., Hou, S., and Hutson, A., 2022, Application of the skew exponential power distribution to ROC curves, Journal of Applied Statistics, 1-16.

Ghitany M., Al-Mutairi D. K., Balakrishnan N., and Al-Enezi L., 2013, Power lindley distribution and associated inference, Computational Statistics & Data Analysis, 64,20–33.

Liu, X., 2012, Classification accuracy and cut point selection, Statistics in medicine, 31(23), 2676-2686.

Nahm, F. S., 2022, Receiver operating characteristic curve: overview and practical use for clinicians, Korean journal of anesthesiology, 75(1), 25-36.

Perkins, N. J., and Schisterman, E. F., 2006, The inconsistency of “optimal” cutpoints obtained using two criteria based on the receiver operating characteristic curve, American journal of epidemiology, 163(7), 670-675.

Pundir, S. and Amala, R., 2014, Evaluation of area under the constant shape bi-weibull roc curve, Journal of Modern Applied Statistical Methods, 13(1),1-20.

Youden, W. J., 1950, Index for rating diagnostic tests, Cancer, 3(1), 32-35.

Examples

dPLD(c(1,2,3,4,5,200),alpha=3,beta=2)
#> [1]  1.082682e+00  1.620507e-05  3.560890e-21  1.070039e-52 3.363180e-105
#> [6]  0.000000e+00
pPLD(c(.5,1,2,3,4),alpha=3,beta=2)
#> [1] 0.1562992 0.7744412 0.9999993 1.0000000 1.0000000
qPLD(c(.9971,0.5,0.3),alpha=3,beta=2)
#> [1] 1.5220612 0.7868721 0.6362570
rPLD(10,alpha=3,beta=2)
#>  [1] 0.9765123 0.8569072 0.9500542 0.9622502 1.2510099 0.8269140 0.6873833
#>  [8] 0.9226734 1.0133698 0.9303568
plAUC(alpha1=2,beta1=5,alpha2=6,beta2=1)
#> [1] 0.9688111
plJ(alpha1=2,beta1=5,alpha2=6,beta2=1,init=0)
#> $par
#> [1] 0.7345928
#> 
#> $value
#> [1] -0.8241212
#> 
#> $counts
#> function gradient 
#>       16       16 
#> 
#> $convergence
#> [1] 0
#> 
#> $message
#> [1] "CONVERGENCE: REL_REDUCTION_OF_F <= FACTR*EPSMCH"
#> 
plER(alpha1=2,beta1=5,alpha2=6,beta2=1,init=0)
#> $par
#> [1] 0.7430008
#> 
#> $value
#> [1] 0.1247003
#> 
#> $counts
#> function gradient 
#>       11       11 
#> 
#> $convergence
#> [1] 0
#> 
#> $message
#> [1] "CONVERGENCE: REL_REDUCTION_OF_F <= FACTR*EPSMCH"
#> 
plCZ(alpha1=2,beta1=5,alpha2=6,beta2=1,init=0)
#> $par
#> [1] 0.736217
#> 
#> $value
#> [1] -0.831771
#> 
#> $counts
#> function gradient 
#>       17       17 
#> 
#> $convergence
#> [1] 0
#> 
#> $message
#> [1] "CONVERGENCE: REL_REDUCTION_OF_F <= FACTR*EPSMCH"
#> 
plIU(alpha1=2,beta1=5,alpha2=6,beta2=1,init=0)
#> $par
#> [1] 0.7345927
#> 
#> $value
#> [1] 0.113501
#> 
#> $counts
#> function gradient 
#>       12       12 
#> 
#> $convergence
#> [1] 0
#> 
#> $message
#> [1] "CONVERGENCE: REL_REDUCTION_OF_F <= FACTR*EPSMCH"
#> 
plNI(alpha1=2,beta1=5,alpha2=6,beta2=1,init=0.5)
#> $par
#> [1] 0.7873601
#> 
#> $value
#> [1] -0.01326588
#> 
#> $counts
#> function gradient 
#>        6        6 
#> 
#> $convergence
#> [1] 0
#> 
#> $message
#> [1] "CONVERGENCE: REL_REDUCTION_OF_F <= FACTR*EPSMCH"
#> 
x=c(1,2,3,4)
y=c(2,3,4)
plROC(x,y,alpha1=2,beta1=5,alpha2=6,beta2=1,empirical=FALSE)

prfROC(ctp=0.5,alpha1=2,beta1=5,alpha2=6,beta2=1)
#>  Sensitivitiy   Specificity 1-Specificity 
#>     0.9921878     0.6538067     0.3461933
